Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back marked with single lines for clypeus, prothorax and elytra and small triangles marking winglets on either side behind the prothorax line; at side, legs quite well-modelled with undercut triangle; underside bearing a hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically, naming Amun-Ra, above neb- basket sign; motif stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; longitudinally pierced; pale green glaze; cream off-white core.
Curator's comments: The faience object was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). Petrie's drawing indicates that the inscription displayed on this scarab was reproduced on several scarabs in glazed composition and Egyptian blue produced in the 'Scarab Factory' (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 90; on the various productions of the 'Scarab Factory', see Webb forthcoming). Numerous variants of the name of Amun-Ra were discovered on scarabs and scaraboids in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 89-93; Gardner 1888, pl. 18, 25 and 36), without including all the different cryptographic writings of Amun on Naukratis scarabs and scaraboids. This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B97-117, see especially B97 for this piece). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 90)
